Award.AbstractNarration: Abstract<br/><br/>Award: DMS-0806037<br/>Principal Investigator: Michael L. Hutchings<br/><br/>The main part of the project is to develop "embedded contact<br/>homology" (ECH), a new invariant of a contact three-manifold,<br/>which is defined in terms of periodic orbits of the Reeb flow and<br/>embedded pseudoholomorphic curves in the symplectization. ECH is<br/>conjecturally isomorphic to versions of the Seiberg-Witten and<br/>Ozsvath-Szabo Floer homologies. Some specific goals of the<br/>project are to further develop the analytical foundations of ECH;<br/>to create tools for computing ECH, particularly in terms of open<br/>book decompositions; to use ECH to obtain lower bounds on numbers<br/>of Reeb orbits; and to work towards extending ECH to a more<br/>general theory which would unify it with the Ozsvath-Szabo Floer<br/>homology. Some broader goals are to use ECH machinery to help<br/>compute symplectic field theory in three dimensions, and to<br/>explore Floer-theoretic invariants of families.<br/><br/>The embedded contact homology developed in this project lies on<br/>the interface between dynamics and low-dimensional topology.<br/>Dynamics is concerned with the behavior of physical systems over<br/>time, while low-dimensional topology studies the possible shapes<br/>of curved spaces in three and four dimensions. Embedded contact<br/>homology allows one to obtain deep topological information from<br/>an understanding of dynamics; and conversely to obtain important<br/>dynamical information, such as the existence of stable<br/>configurations, from topological conditions.

Institution.Name: University of California-Berkeley
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE
